unnormalised: ## The Great Indian Return Tamasha: Na Baba Na!
normalised: ## The Great Indian Return Tamasha: N A Baba N A!

unnormalised: Let's face it, folks. Returning stuff, especially in India, is often more dramatic than a Karan Johar movie. We've all been there. Staring down a shopkeeper with the unwavering gaze of a seasoned bargainer, trying to return that ghastly green kurta your phuphi *insisted* was "perfect for Diwali." It's a national sport, really.
normalised: Let's face it, folks. Returning stuff, especially in India, is often more dramatic than a Karan Johar movie. We've all been there. Staring down a shopkeeper with the unwavering gaze of a seasoned bargainer, trying to return that ghastly green kurta your phuphi *insisted* was "perfect for Diwali." It's a national sport, really.

unnormalised: And online? Don't even get me started. You excitedly order that fancy new "imported" Bluetooth speaker, only to receive a box filled with... well, let's just say it's less speaker, more strategically placed packing peanuts and a single, disgruntled-looking ant. Return time!
normalised: And online? Don't even get me started. You excitedly order that fancy new "imported" Bluetooth speaker, only to receive a box filled with... well, let's just say it's less speaker, more strategically placed packing peanuts and a single, disgruntled-looking ant. Return time!

unnormalised: But here's where the fun REALLY begins. Navigating the murky waters of return policies. Every e-commerce site boasts about "hassle-free returns," but the reality often involves more hassle than trying to get a seat on a Mumbai local train at 09:00 hrs.
normalised: But here's where the fun R E A L L Y begins. Navigating the murky waters of return policies. Every e-commerce site boasts about "hassle-free returns," but the reality often involves more hassle than trying to get a seat on a Mumbai local train at zero nine hundred hours.

unnormalised: You'll need your original bill (dating back to, like, 15/08/1947 if you're anything like my dad), all the original packaging (including that tiny plastic bag the spare button came in), and a perfectly plausible explanation for why this "as good as new" item is, in fact, utterly useless.

unnormalised: "But madam, did you try turning it on? And connecting it to your Wi-Fi? And praying to Lord Ganesha?"
normalised: "But madam, did you try turning it on? And connecting it to your Wi-Fi? And praying to Lord Ganesha?"

unnormalised: Sometimes, you feel like you're being interviewed for a government job. The whole process can take weeks, leading to more stress than planning a wedding in Chandni Chowk. And then, FINALLY, maybe, just *maybe*, you'll get your refund.
normalised: Sometimes, you feel like you're being interviewed for a government job. The whole process can take weeks, leading to more stress than planning a wedding in Chandni Chowk. And then, F I N A L L Y, maybe, just *maybe*, you'll get your refund.

unnormalised: Remember that time I tried to return a saree I bought online on 26/01/2023? Turns out, "Easy Returns" meant "Easy For Us To Say No, Returns Are Impossible." They claimed the saree had been "damaged" (by the mere act of existing, apparently).
normalised: Remember that time I tried to return a saree I bought online on twenty sixth january two thousand and twenty three? Turns out, "Easy Returns" meant "Easy For Us To Say No, Returns Are Impossible." They claimed the saree had been "damaged" (by the mere act of existing, apparently).

unnormalised: So, before you hit that "Buy Now" button, take a deep breath. Read the return policy. Twice. Maybe even three times. And mentally prepare yourself for the Great Indian Return Tamasha. Because, as they say, sometimes keeping the dud is less painful than dealing with the return. Especially if it's something your mother-in-law bought you. That's a whole other blog post waiting to happen.
